questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a diagnosis of mucopolysaccharidosis, characterized by the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). One GAG that has accumulated is known to play a critical role in the charge selectiveness of the renal glomerular membrane. Which of the following GAGs is responsible for maintaining the charge selectiveness of the renal glomerular membrane?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Heparan sulphate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Dermatan sulphate : found in skin, blood vessels and heart valves and determines the elasticity of heart valve and skin.
  • • Option B: Dermatan sulphate
  • • Option C: Hyaluronic acid : present in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid and vitreous humor and acts as a lubricant and shock absorber in joint cavities.
  • • Option C: Hyaluronic acid
  • • Option D: Keratan sulphate : only GAG, which does not contain uronic acid and found in cornea and tendons, thereby maintaining corneal transparency.
  • • Option D: Keratan sulphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heparan sulfate is a key component of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and contributes to its negative charge. This charge barrier is essential for the selective filtration of molecules based on size and charge.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis constant (Km)?

options.label: C
options.text: Not a characteristic feature of enzymes

options.label: D
options.text: A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity: This statement is incorrect. The substrate concentration at maximum velocity is not specifically defined by Km , as Vmax is reached at much higher substrate concentrations where all enzyme active sites are saturated.
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity:
  • • substrate concentration
  • • maximum velocity
  • • not specifically defined by Km
  • • Option C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes: This statement is incorrect. Km is indeed a characteristic feature of enzymes and is crucial in the study of enzyme kinetics.
  • • Option
  • • C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes:
  • • Km
  • • characteristic feature of enzymes
  • • Option D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation: This statement is incorrect. A low Km value actually indicates a high affinity of the enzyme for its substrate, as it means the enzyme can achieve half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration.
  • • Option
  • • D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation:
  • • low Km value
  • • high affinity of the enzyme
  • • substrate,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Km value is substrate concentration (expressed in moles/L) at half-maximal velocity. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration. It is independent of enzyme concentration . It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely connected to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates . So, less the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

  • ➤ It is independent of enzyme concentration .
  • ➤ independent of enzyme concentration
  • ➤ It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate.

questions.text: Which of the following theory/model explains the mode of action of enzyme mentioned in the picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Michaelis–Menten model: Enzyme-Substrate complex theory -The enzyme (E) combines with the substrate (S) → enzyme-substrate (ES) complex → immediately breaks down to the enzyme and the product (P).
  • • Option B. Michaelis–Menten model: Enzyme-Substrate complex theory
  • • →
  • • →
  • • E + S → E–S Complex → E + P
  • • E + S → E–S Complex → E + P
  • • Option C. Lock and key model: Fischer’s Template Theory- This theory states that the three-dimensional structures of the active site of the enzyme is complementary to the substrate → [E] and [S] fit each other similar to lock and key.
  • • Option C. Lock and key model: Fischer’s Template Theory-
  • • three-dimensional structures
  • • active site
  • • enzyme
  • • complementary to the substrate →

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal graphical representation of the Michaelis-Menten equation . However, the Michaelis-Menten model assumes that the enzyme-substrate complex is static and does not account for changes in the enzyme structure upon substrate binding . In contrast, the induced fit model posits that the enzyme structure is flexible and changes to accommodate the substrate upon binding, which is not directly observable in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a diagnosed urea cycle disorder presents with recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia, especially after high-protein meals. Despite dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavenging medications, the child's ammonia levels remain intermittently elevated, leading to concerns about long-term neurological outcomes. The metabolic specialist considers augmenting the treatment regimen. Which combination of supplements could provide an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion and help manage the child's condition more effectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Arginine and glutamine: Glutamine is often elevated in UCDs as it binds with free ammonia ; however, supplementation with glutamine is not typically used for treatment because the body is already producing excess.
  • • Option
  • • A. Arginine and glutamine:
  • • Glutamine
  • • elevated in UCDs
  • • binds with free ammonia
  • • Option B. Lysine and glutamine: Lysine is not specifically involved in the urea cycle , and, as mentioned, glutamine is typically already elevated in UCDs.
  • • Option
  • • B. Lysine and glutamine:
  • • not
  • • involved in the urea cycle
  • • Option D. Lysine and benzoate: Lysine is not a supplement used in the management of UCDs , and while benzoate is used, it would not be paired with lysine for treatment.
  • • Option
  • • D. Lysine and benzoate:
  • • not
  • • supplement used in the management of UCDs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders (UCDs) result in the body's inability to properly dispose of waste nitrogen from protein metabolism , leading to hyperammonemia. Arginine supplementation can be beneficial because it provides an essential amino acid that is often deficient in UCDs.

questions.text: A couple with a 5-year-old son diagnosed with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is expecting another child. The mother, currently pregnant, is concerned about her unborn daughter potentially having the same condition, despite both parents being clinically unaffected. Considering the genetic nature of G6PD deficiency, which of the following statements is true regarding the risk to the female fetus?

options.label: A
options.text: The baby has a 25% chance of clinical disease

options.label: B
options.text: The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

options.label: C
options.text: The baby will be a carrier

options.label: D
options.text: The baby has a 50% chance of clinical disease

questions.correct_answer: B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Here's how the inheritance works:
  • • Males (XY): If they inherit the defective X chromosome, they express the disease because they have only one X. Females (XX): Need two defective X chromosomes to express the disease. If they inherit one defective X, they are typically carriers.
  • • Males (XY): If they inherit the defective X chromosome, they express the disease because they have only one X.
  • • Males (XY):
  • • Females (XX): Need two defective X chromosomes to express the disease. If they inherit one defective X, they are typically carriers.
  • • Females (XX):
  • • In this scenario:
  • • In this scenario:
  • • The son is affected, meaning he must have inherited the defective X chromosome from his mother. Both parents are clinically unaffected, so: The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The son is affected, meaning he must have inherited the defective X chromosome from his mother.
  • • Both parents are clinically unaffected, so: The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and
  • • The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • When a carrier mother (XᴺXᴰ) and a normal father (XᴺY) have a daughter, the daughter has:
  • • 50% chance of being a carrier (XᴺXᴰ) 50% chance of being completely normal (XᴺXᴺ)
  • • 50% chance of being a carrier (XᴺXᴰ)
  • • 50% chance of being completely normal (XᴺXᴺ)
  • • Thus, the risk to the female fetus is 50% chance of being a carrier.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. A female would need two defective X chromosomes to be affected, which isn't the case here. Option C. The baby will be a carrier : Incorrect. There’s a 50% chance, not 100%. Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. Females are typically only carriers unless both X chromosomes are defective.
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. A female would need two defective X chromosomes to be affected, which isn't the case here.
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease
  • • Option C. The baby will be a carrier : Incorrect. There’s a 50% chance, not 100%.
  • • Option C. The baby will be a carrier
  • • Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. Females are typically only carriers unless both X chromosomes are defective.
  • • Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. It affects the pentose phosphate pathway, reducing the production of NADPH, which is essential for maintaining reduced glutathione that protects cells from oxidative damage. This condition predominantly affects males, while female carriers are usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the orthopedic outpatient department with joint swelling and pain, as depicted in the image. The physical examination reveals swollen, erythematous joints with tenderness. Laboratory tests show elevated serum uric acid levels. She is diagnosed with gout. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium urate crystals can deposit in kidneys and impair renal function

options.label: C
options.text: Uric acid overproduction is seen in myeloproliferative disorders like leukemia

options.label: D
options.text: Allopurinol used in treatment as it inhibits xanthine oxidase

questions.correct_answer: A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis – Incorrect (Correct Answer) This is incorrect because decreased activity of PRPP synthetase reduces purine synthesis. In contrast, increased (not decreased) activity of PRPP synthetase leads to enhanced purine synthesis and overproduction of uric acid, contributing to gout. Therefore, the statement is wrong.
  • • Option A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis – Incorrect (Correct Answer) This is incorrect because decreased activity of PRPP synthetase reduces purine synthesis. In contrast, increased (not decreased) activity of PRPP synthetase leads to enhanced purine synthesis and overproduction of uric acid, contributing to gout. Therefore, the statement is wrong.
  • • Option A. PRPP synthetase decreased activity can contribute to gout by increasing purine synthesis – Incorrect (Correct Answer)
  • • incorrect
  • • decreased activity
  • • reduces
  • • increased (not decreased) activity
  • • enhanced purine synthesis
  • • gout.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sodium urate crystals can deposit in kidneys and impair renal function – True In chronic gout , urate crystals can deposit in the renal parenchyma and tubules, leading to urate nephropathy and potential renal failure. Option C. Uric acid overproduction is seen in myeloproliferative disorders like leukemia – True Leukemias and other myeloproliferative disorders involve rapid cell turnover and breakdown of nucleic acids, leading to hyperuricemia and secondary gout. Option D. Allopurinol used in treatment as it inhibits xanthine oxidase – True Allopurinol is a inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, reducing the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid, making it effective for long-term management of gout.
  • • Option B. Sodium urate crystals can deposit in kidneys and impair renal function – True In chronic gout , urate crystals can deposit in the renal parenchyma and tubules, leading to urate nephropathy and potential renal failure.

  • • renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describe DNA repair processes?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA repair of double strand breaks is error free.

options.label: B
options.text: DNA repair of mismatched bases repairs the parental strand.

options.label: C
options.text: Repair of uracil formed by deamination of cytosine need the actions of endo and exonucleases to remove the uracil base.

options.label: D
options.text: Repair of ultraviolet radiation–induced pyrimidine dimers formation involves removal of a short oligonucleotide sequence containing the dimer.

questions.correct_answer: D. Repair of ultraviolet radiation–induced pyrimidine dimers formation involves removal of a short oligonucleotide sequence containing the dimer.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Repair of ultraviolet radiation–induced pyrimidine dimers formation involves removal of a short oligonucleotide sequence containing the dimer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: DNA repair of double strand breaks is error free (Incorrect): There is nothing like “error free’’ in DNA repair but the homologous -recombination method is less prone to error than the Non homologous–end-joining method .
  • • Option A: DNA repair of double strand breaks is error free (Incorrect):
  • • homologous -recombination method
  • • Non homologous–end-joining method
  • • Option B: DNA repair of mismatched bases repairs the parental strand (Incorrect): identification and repair of the newly synthesized strand.
  • • Option B: DNA repair of mismatched bases repairs the parental strand (Incorrect):
  • • Option C: Repair of uracil formed by deamination of cytosine need the actions of endo and exonucleases to remove the uracil base (Incorrect): Base excision repair: uracil is removed from DNA, utilizes a glycosylase to remove the base → forms an apyrimidinic or apurinic (AP) site → removal of sugar-phosphate by endo- and exonuclease.
  • • Option C: Repair of uracil formed by deamination of cytosine need the actions of endo and exonucleases to remove the uracil base (Incorrect):

NER involves the removal of a short single-stranded DNA segment that includes the dimer, followed by DNA synthesis using the intact strand as a template.

questions.text: When discussing the differences between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100 proteins, which are both derived from the same ApoB gene but expressed differently in the intestine and liver, respectively, it's crucial to understand the molecular mechanism responsible for their diversity. These proteins are vital for lipid metabolism, with Apo-B48 being involved in chylomicron formation and Apo-B100 in VLDL and LDL. What process leads to the production of these distinct proteins from the same mRNA transcript?
questions.correct_answer: C. Deamination of cytidine to uridine
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Deamination of Cytidine to Uridine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. RNA splicing: While RNA splicing is a common mechanism to generate protein diversity by removing introns from the pre-mRNA, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100. These proteins result from the same gene and mRNA transcript but differ due to a specific editing event.
  • • Option A. RNA splicing:
  • • RNA splicing
  • • common mechanism
  • • generate protein diversity
  • • Option B. Allelic exclusion: This process, where only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other is silenced , is not related to the production of Apo-B48 and Apo-B100. These proteins come from the same mRNA transcript and gene but are differentially processed in different tissues.
  • • Option B. Allelic exclusion:
  • • only one allele of a gene is expressed
  • • other is silenced
  • • Option D. Upstream repression: This refers to a regulatory mechanism where gene expression is inhibited by factors binding to regions upstream of the gene . This mechanism does not explain the production of two different proteins from the same mRNA transcript as seen with Apo-B48 and Apo-B100.
  • • Option D. Upstream repression:
  • • regulatory mechanism
  • • gene expression is inhibited by factors binding to regions upstream of the gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The difference between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100 arises from the editing of the ApoB mRNA through the deamination of a specific cytidine to uridine in the intestinal cells . This conversion creates a stop codon in the mRNA, leading to the production of the shorter Apo-B48 protein in the intestine. In contrast, the liver cells do not perform this editing, resulting in the full-length Apo-B100 protein.
  • ➤ difference between Apo-B48
  • ➤ Apo-B100 arises from the editing

questions.text: Which of the following is found only in cytoplasm: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glycolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Correct Answer. Glycolysis, the process of breaking down glucose to pyruvate, occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm. It is the first major pathway of glucose catabolism and occurs in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Glycolysis is unique among these options as being the only pathway confined to the cytoplasm.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CA Cycle: The Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, takes place in the mitochondria, not in the cytoplasm. It is a key metabolic pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, leading to the production of ATP.
  • • Option A. CA Cycle:
  • • Option B. Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids: Beta-oxidation, the process of breaking down fatty acids to produce acetyl-CoA, occurs in the mitochondria. In some cells, like liver cells, it can also occur in peroxisomes, but it does not take place in the cytoplasm.
  • • Option B. Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids:
  • • Option D. Gluconeogenesis: Although some steps of gluconeogenesis occur in the cytoplasm, it is not exclusive to this compartment. This metabolic pathway, which generates glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates, involves steps that occur in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria (and to a lesser extent, the endoplasmic reticulum).
  • • Option D. Gluconeogenesis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generally, all Anabolic Pathways occur in Cytoplasm and all Catabolic Pathways occur in Mitochondria Exception: Two catabolic pathways also occur in cytoplasm. Glycolysis Glycogenolysis

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibitor in the graph? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibitor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a Lineweaver-Burk plot of enzyme kinetics, with 1/v (inverse of velocity) on the Y-axis and 1/[S] (inverse of substrate concentration) on the X-axis. The red line represents the inhibitor, and the blue line represents the normal substrate.
  • • In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, the Km (Michaelis constant) increases while the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. This is evident in the graph where the slope increases, indicating an increased Km, but the Y-intercept, representing 1/Vmax, stays the same.
  • • For non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged. This would be shown by an increase in the Y-intercept, which is not the case here.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor: In non-competitive inhibition, the Vmax decreases while the Km remains unchanged. This would be reflected in the graph by an increased Y-intercept (1/Vmax) while the slope remains the same, which is not observed here.
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor:
  • • Option C. Allosteric inhibitor: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site and can either increase or decrease enzyme activity, affecting both Km and Vmax. The specific effects depend on the nature of the allosteric inhibition, which is not represented by the given Lineweaver-Burk plot.
  • • Option C. Allosteric inhibitor:
  • • Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. This would be shown by parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is not seen in the provided graph.
  • • Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive inhibitors increase the Km without affecting the Vmax, which is shown by an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot without changing the Y-intercept.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 77

questions.text: RNAi acts through? ( INICET May 2021

  • • Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.
  • • Option A. Knock out:
  • • Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.
  • • Option C. Knock in:
  • • Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.
  • • Option D. Knock up:

Educational Objective:

  • • C banding
  • • So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.
  • • Option A. G-banding:
  • • Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option B. NOR-banding:

  • • Option D. R-banding:
  • • Note – Q banding : uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.
  • • Note – Q banding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad.
  • ➤ an autosomal recessive
  • ➤ The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria . Crystalluria and calculi formation . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test . Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake . Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.

Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.

questions.text: Which of the following compound(s) is most likely to cause diabetic cataract:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Accumulation of galactose + glucose: Not the primary cause Galactose is a sugar that can also accumulate in the lens, but it's not the primary cause of diabetic cataract. Galactose accumulation is more related to galactosemia, a rare genetic disorder.
  • • Option B. Accumulation of galactose + glucose: Not the primary cause
  • • Option C. Accumulation of galactitol + glucose: Not the primary cause Galactitol is a sugar alcohol that accumulates in the lens in galactosemia, not in diabetes. While it can contribute to cataract formation, it's not the primary cause of diabetic cataract.
  • • Option C. Accumulation of galactitol + glucose: Not the primary cause
  • • Option D. Accumulation of glucose only: Not the primary cause Glucose accumulation alone doesn't directly cause cataract formation. It's the conversion of glucose to sorbitol through aldose reductase that leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation.
  • • Option D. Accumulation of glucose only: Not the primary cause

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The accumulation of sorbitol is the most likely cause of diabetic cataract, due to the osmotic stress it causes in the lens.

questions.text: Cause of formation of ketone bodies in Diabetic Ketoacidosis are all EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Acetyl CoA not participating in TCA Cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Increased activity of beta hydroxy butyrate dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: Mobilization of fats from adipose tissue

questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is a metabolic state characterized by the formation of ketone bodies. Here's a breakdown of each option:
  • • Option A. Acetyl CoA not participating in TCA Cycle : Correct. In DKA, the liver produces excess acetyl-CoA, which cannot enter the TCA cycle due to a lack of oxaloacetate (a key intermediate). Instead, acetyl-CoA is converted to ketone bodies.
  • • Option A. Acetyl CoA not participating in TCA Cycle
  • • Option B. Increased activity of beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase : Correct. This enzyme is involved in the conversion of acetyl-CoA to ketone bodies (specifically, beta-hydroxybutyrate). Increased activity contributes to ketone body formation.
  • • Option B. Increased activity of beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase
  • • Option C. Mobilization of fats from adipose tissue : Correct. In DKA, the body breaks down fat for energy, releasing fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are then converted to acetyl-CoA, leading to ketone body formation.
  • • Option C. Mobilization of fats from adipose tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Options A, B, and C are all correct causes of ketone body formation in DKA, while option D is the exception. Decreased fatty acid oxidation is not a cause of ketone body formation in DKA.

questions.text: All are true about telomerase EXCEPT?
questions.correct_answer: B. Maintains fidelity of DNA replication
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maintains fidelity of DNA replication

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Telomerase is an enzyme that maintains telomere length by adding nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes.
  • • Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: TRUE. Telomerase has reverse transcriptase activity, which allows it to synthesize DNA from an RNA template.
  • • Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: TRUE.
  • • Option C. Maintains length of DNA: TRUE. Telomerase maintains telomere length by adding nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes, preventing shortening during DNA replication.
  • • Option C. Maintains length of DNA: TRUE.
  • • Option D. Found only in eukaryotes: TRUE. Telomerase is found in most eukaryotes, including humans, but not in prokaryotes (bacteria).
  • • Option D. Found only in eukaryotes: TRUE.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase is a reverse transcriptase that:
  • ➤ Synthesizes DNA from an RNA template Maintains telomere length Is found in most eukaryotes
  • ➤ Synthesizes DNA from an RNA template
  • ➤ Maintains telomere length
  • ➤ Is found in most eukaryotes
  • ➤ However, it does not maintain fidelity of DNA replication (this is ensured by other enzymes, like DNA polymerase and proofreading exonucleases)

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 5' UTR (Untranslated Region): NOT the primary binding site, The 5' UTR is involved in translation initiation, but it's not the primary binding site for miRNAs.
  • • Option A. 5' UTR (Untranslated Region): NOT
  • • Option C. Gene promoter: NOT a binding site, The gene promoter is a region upstream of the gene that regulates transcription initiation, but it's not a binding site for miRNAs.
  • • Option C. Gene promoter: NOT
  • • Option D. Gene body: NOT a primary binding site, While some miRNAs can bind to the gene body (exons or introns), the primary binding site is the 3' UTR.
  • • Option D. Gene body: NOT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ miRNAs bind to the 3' UTR through complementary base pairing, leading to:
  • ➤ Translational repression mRNA degradation Regulation of gene expression
  • ➤ Translational repression
  • ➤ mRNA degradation
  • ➤ Regulation of gene expression
  • ➤ The 3' UTR is a key region for post-transcriptional regulation by miRNAs.

questions.text: In MCAD deficiency, during starvation, Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Normal blood glucose: Incorrect, In MCAD deficiency, the body cannot oxidize medium-chain fatty acids, leading to reduced energy production and decreased glucose production (gluconeogenesis). Blood glucose levels may be low.
  • • Option A. Normal blood glucose: Incorrect,
  • • Option B. Ketoacidosis: Incorrect, While ketoacidosis can occur in some fatty acid oxidation disorders, MCAD deficiency typically presents with dicarboxylic acidosis (see below).
  • • Option B. Ketoacidosis: Incorrect,
  • • Option D. Hyperchylomicronemia: Incorrect, Hyperchylomicronemia refers to elevated levels of chylomicrons (lipid-rich lipoproteins) in the blood. While MCAD deficiency affects lipid metabolism, it does not typically cause hyperchylomicronemia.
  • • Option D. Hyperchylomicronemia: Incorrect,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MCAD deficiency, starvation leads to:
  • ➤ Impaired fatty acid oxidation Reduced energy production Decreased glucose production Accumulation of medium-chain fatty acids and dicarboxylic acids
  • ➤ Impaired fatty acid oxidation
  • ➤ Reduced energy production
  • ➤ Decreased glucose production
  • ➤ Accumulation of medium-chain fatty acids and dicarboxylic acids
  • ➤ Dicarboxylic acidosis is a characteristic feature of MCAD deficiency during starvation.
